questions: Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. A coworker who just got promoted asks you to help them move apartments this weekend. How do you respond?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. You're at a networking event and spot someone who works at a company you want to join. They're standing alone. What do you do?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. Your neighbor mentions they're thinking of selling their house, and you've been wanting to expand your property. What do you say?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. A friend who's a hiring manager mentions their team has openings. Your cousin is job hunting. How do you bring it up?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. You're assigned to mentor a new employee who will eventually take over some of your responsibilities. How do you approach it?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. Your landlord asks if you'd be willing to show the apartment to prospective tenants while they're away. What do you say?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. A wealthy relative you rarely talk to invites you to their birthday dinner. How do you respond?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. Your team lead asks for volunteers to present the quarterly results to the VP. Nobody else is raising their hand. What do you do?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. A classmate who always does well on exams asks if you want to form a study group. How do you respond?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. Your boss mentions they're looking for someone to lead a new project that involves travel to the Tokyo office. What do you say?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. An acquaintance with a large social media following asks you to collaborate on a project. How do you respond?

Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. You're at a dinner party and the host introduces you to someone who turns out to be a venture capitalist. You have a startup idea. What do you do?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. A friend going through a divorce asks if you can recommend a good real estate agent â€” you happen to have your license. What do you say?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. Your manager asks who should represent the team at the annual conference in Hawaii. How do you respond?
Be straightforward and transparent about your motivations. A colleague mentions they're overwhelmed and might give up their corner office. What do you say?
